title: Can 13.6 billion years of time pass without someone to observe that time passing? - Quora

response.answer_text: You’re using technical terms in their everyday sense, and that’s where the confusion is coming from. The phrase “Someone to observe”, makes me think that you think that quantum mechanics cares about consciousness to “make an observation”. It doesn’t. Particles observe each other all the time with no scientist watching. So events can totally unfold with “no one observing”, but less so with “nothing observing”. Time, though is an illusion. There is 4 dimensional extent; that’s real. But the notion that the future doesn’t exist, and springs into being from nothing moment by moment is false. Our sense of the “Flow of time” is an evolutionary adaptation. It’s like the tree falling in the woods. You can bet that it produces a shock wave in the air (a real phenomenon, just like 4D extent), but without an animal it will in fact not produce a sound (a perception, like the passage of time). So now you get to pick your definitions, and thereby your own answer!

The correct answer is, “no”. Time is not a “thing” in the sense that we normally think of time. Time is a construct, a concept, that allows us to understand the changing of the universe. We know that “time” has passed because we can deduce the past, but if there is no one to observe “time” passing, then the construct of “time” does not exist, and therefore it cannot pass. That being said, in the scientific sense, there really isn’t any “time” to begin with - there is only “spacetime”. So in that sense, yes, the universe could could go on changing and entropy could go on growing, with or without an observer - but the concept of time as we think of it would be irrelevant, without minds.

According to the theory of Last Thursdayism, everything in the universe was created last Thursday, complete with everyone’s memories and all features in the universe. It is a silly theory, but it allows for one to present the idea that 13.6 Billions years of evidence could be created at an arbitrary instant called last Thursday and we would never know the difference. Here is one screwy example of this theory, www The Church of Last-Thursday.

As an astronomer, I assure you that we can see back in time - when the Universe was 380,000 years old, it emitted CMB. And we can construct its history from that era to present with great accuracy. (In fact, we can go much further back, to 1 second since the Universe was created.) This is because of the fact that light takes certain time to reach to travel. The Universe is homogeneous and isotropic - meaning it looks same at every direction, and no place is special. However, Universe looked different when it was younger. You go 12 billion years ago, and there are almost no galaxy. The metallicity of these galaxies is also different compared to the current ones.
No, anything that exists needs consciousness to observe it… so the ultimate consciousness of Almighty God had to be around to observe this reality we call our universe.
